review.title: Spatially-Adaptive Reconstruction in Computed Tomography using Neural Networks
review.abstract: We propose a supervised machine learning approach for boosting existing signal and image recovery methods and demonstrate its efficacy on example of image reconstruction in computed tomography. Our technique is based on a local nonlinear fusion of several image estimates, all obtained by applying a chosen reconstruction algorithm with different values of its control parameters. Usually such output images have different bias/variance trade-off. The fusion of the images is performed by feed-forward neural network trained on a set of known examples. Numerical experiments show an improvement in reconstruction quality relatively to existing direct and iterative reconstruction methods.

sections.heading: VIII. COMPUTATIONAL COMPLEXITY OF THE METHOD
sections.text: We analyze the number of calculations required for the proposed method in the cases of FBP and PWLS reconstruction. First, we consider the complexity of using ANN to perform pixel-by-pixel fusion from a number of image versions created during the reconstruction phase. However, an n · n image requires n2 activations of ANN. Typically, the dimension of the ANN input vector is in the order of 100 samples, the output dimension has up to 5 elements, and a single hidden layer of up to 40 neurons is used. Thus, the 12network contains 40 · 100 + 5 · 40 = 4200 weight4. Each neuron also implements a sigmoid function, requiring 40 sigmoid calculations to generate the ANN output values. Therefore, the cost of performing a local fusion by ANN is 4200 · n3 operations. If the method for reconstructing the BP is used, a number of FBP reconstructions must be present in our three BP reconstructions; if the BP is sufficient in our three BP reconstructions, the number of times is sufficient.

sections.heading: IX. SUMMARY
sections.text: The concept consists of two components: firstly, the behaviour of the signal in its different versions is recorded; secondly, the ANN performs its own non-linear filtering of the signal versions in small neighbourhoods of the estimated pixel; the proposed method is very general and CT reconstruction is only one possible application for it; local fusion can be used to solve any linear, non-linear inverse problem where an algorithm exists to create a solution estimation; and the proposed method will make it possible to integrate the algorithm outputs generated with different values of a core parameter into a single improved result, eliminating the need to coordinate this parameter; and the proposed method will make it possible to integrate the algorithm outputs generated with different values of a core parameter when the local results of the FBP fusion are very good and the FBP results cannot be improved on the basis of the available resolution.
